skills.name: Identify the net of a prism
Identify the net of a non-prism
Draw the net of a prism

explanations.A: A triangle is a three-sided 2D shape with straight edges. This net will fold into a 3D shape.
explanations.B: A triangular prism has a triangular face at each end, plus three rectangular faces. Which 3D shape would only have two faces, as shown in this net?
explanations.C: A triangular-based pyramid would have 4 triangular faces. Which 3D shape would have two faces, as shown on this net?
explanations.D: A cone has two faces. The base is a circle and then a single face in the shape of a sector creates the curved surface area.

explanations.A: A triangle is a three-sided 2D shape with straight edges. This net will fold into a 3D shape. What shape will the face on the base be?
explanations.B: A triangular prism has a triangular face at each end, plus three rectangular faces. Which 3D shape would have one square and 4 triangular faces?
explanations.C: A triangular-based pyramid would have 4 triangular faces. Which 3D shape would have one square and 4 triangular faces?
explanations.D: A square-based pyramid has one square face surrounded by 4 triangular faces.

explanations.A: A triangle is a 2D shape. A net forms a 3D shape.
explanations.B: The two triangles will form the two identical end faces of a triangular prism. The squares will fold up to form the connecting sides.
explanations.C: A triangular-based pyramid has 4 triangular faces. This net has some faces that are not triangles.
explanations.D: An icosahedron has 20 triangular faces. This net has some faces that are not triangles.

explanations.A: A rectangle is a 2D shape. A net forms a 3D shape.
explanations.B: This forms a cuboid with three pairs of identical rectangles that are opposite each other.
explanations.C: The faces of a cube are identical squares. This net has faces of different sizes.
explanations.D: A rectangle-based pyramid has 4 triangular faces. This net does not have any triangular faces.

explanations.A: A triangle is a three-sided 2D shape with straight edges. This net will fold into a 3D shape. Which 3D shape would have four triangular faces as shown in the diagram?
explanations.B: A triangular prism has a triangular face at each end, plus three rectangular faces. Which 3D shape would have four triangular faces as shown in the net?
explanations.C: A triangular-based prism would have 4 triangular faces.
explanations.D: An icosahedron has 20 faces. Which 3D shape has four triangular faces?

explanations.A: A frustum is the remaining shape when the top of a cone or pyramid is cut off. The two circular faces are parallel to each other, with the other face making up the curved surface between them.
explanations.B: A cone has one circular face. Which 3D shape would have one circular face smaller than the other?
explanations.C: A cylinder has two identical circular faces. Which 3D shape would have one circular face smaller than the other?
explanations.D: A sphere does not have 3 faces. Which 3D shape would have two different sized circular faces?

explanations.A: A pentagonal prism would have a pentagon-shaped face at either end. How many pentagons in total would we need to draw this?
explanations.B: A pentagonal prism would have a pentagon-shaped face at either end. But what shape would make up the faces in between them?
explanations.C: A pentagonal prism would have a pentagon-shaped face at either end. How many pentagons in total would we need to draw this?
explanations.D: A pentagonal prism would have a pentagon-shaped face at either end, with rectangles joining up the corresponding edges.

explanations.A: A hexagonal prism would have a hexagon shaped face at either end. How many hexagons would you need in total to draw this net?
explanations.B: A hexagonal prism would have a hexagon-shaped face at either end, with rectangles joining up the corresponding edges.
explanations.C: A hexagonal prism would have a hexagon shaped face at either end. How many hexagons would you need in total to draw this net?
explanations.D: A hexagonal prism would have a hexagon-shaped face at either end. What shape would make up the faces in between them?

explanations.A: A pyramid always has some triangular sides. This net has none.
explanations.B: The two hexagons will form the two identical end faces of a hexagonal prism. The squares will fold around to form the connecting sides.
explanations.C: A hexagon is a 2D shape. A net forms a 3D shape.
explanations.D: This shape does form a 3D shape. Imagine the two hexagons folding up and then the squares folding around them. What will this create?

explanations.A: An octagon is a 2D shape. A net forms a 3D shape.
explanations.B: A pyramid always has some triangular sides. This net has none.
explanations.C: The two octagons will form the two identical end faces of a octagonal prism. The squares will fold around to form the connecting sides.
explanations.D: This shape does form a 3D shape. Imagine the two octagons folding up and then the squares folding around them. What will this create?
